entity1.name: Satellites
entity1.description: Artificial objects placed in orbit around the Earth to facilitate communication and other services.;;;Artificial objects placed in orbit around the Earth to facilitate communication, weather prediction, and other scientific or military functions.;;;The industry involved in transmitting audio or video content to a wide audience through media channels like radio or television.;;;The exchange of information over significant distances by electronic means and related technology.;;;Satellites that orbit the Earth at a lower altitude compared to other types of satellites, typically used for Earth observation, remote sensing, and satellite internet.;;;Artificial objects placed in orbit around the Earth to facilitate telecommunications and broadcasting.;;;Artificial objects placed in orbit around the Earth to facilitate communication, navigation, and data collection.;;;A specific type of Earth-orbiting satellite designed to relay signals for television, internet, phone calls, and other forms of communication.;;;Artificial objects launched into orbit around the Earth or other celestial bodies to perform various functions.;;;An object that orbits around a larger body in space.;;;The scientific and engineering discipline concerned with the design, development, deployment, and operation of satellites for various applications.;;;Artificial objects placed in orbit around the Earth to facilitate communication, navigation, and other services.;;;A field of technology that involves the use of artificial satellites for various applications such as communication, navigation, and Earth observation.;;;The field of technology that deals with communication over a distance using various methods such as telephones, radio, television, and the internet.;;;A type of satellite that orbits the Earth at the same speed as Earth's rotation, allowing it to remain fixed over a specific point on the equator.;;;An artificial object that has been intentionally placed into orbit around a celestial body, such as Earth.;;;Satellites used to observe and monitor weather conditions from space.;;;A type of spacecraft propulsion that uses electrical energy to accelerate propellants, enabling more efficient satellite maneuvers and extended operational lifetimes.;;;Artificial objects launched into orbit around the Earth or other celestial bodies, used for various purposes such as communication, navigation, and observation.;;;The technology and methods used to move a spacecraft or satellite through space or the atmosphere.;;;Man-made objects launched into space to orbit a celestial body and perform various functions.;;;The sector of the economy focused on manufacturing, launching, and operating satellites for various applications such as communication, navigation, and Earth observation.;;;An orbit around Earth with an altitude of 2,000 km or less.;;;Artificial objects placed in orbit around the Earth or other celestial bodies to serve various purposes such as communication, navigation, and observation.;;;The field of developing and using artificial satellites for various applications such as communication, navigation, and Earth observation.;;;Systems designed for transmitting information from one place to another, often used in satellites for data transfer and control.;;;Satellites equipped with sensors and cameras to monitor weather patterns.;;;Satellites used for scientific studies, including Earth's climate, oceans, atmosphere, and land cover.;;;A high Earth orbit where satellites are positioned to match the Earth's rotation, appearing stationary over a fixed point on the equator.;;;Artificial objects placed in orbit around the Earth to serve various purposes such as communication, navigation, and observation.;;;A man-made object that orbits the Earth and is used for various purposes such as communication, navigation, and observation.

entity2.name: Earth
entity2.description: The boundless three-dimensional extent in which objects and events have relative position and direction, particularly the area beyond Earth's atmosphere where celestial bodies exist.;;;The expanse that exists beyond Earth's atmosphere, containing celestial bodies such as stars, planets, and galaxies.;;;The third planet from the Sun, also known as our home planet.;;;The third planet from the Sun and the only astronomical object known to harbor life.
entity2.chunkid: How Satellites Work25;;;How Satellites Work5;;;How Satellites Work10;;;How Satellites Work2;;;How Satellites Work16;;;How Satellites Work9;;;How Satellites Work18

entity4.name: weather forecasting
entity4.description: The application of science and technology to predict the state of the atmosphere for a future time and given location.

entity5.name: scientific research
entity5.description: Systematic investigation into and study of materials, structures, or phenomena to discover facts and formulate laws.

entity6.name: national security
entity6.description: A concept that a government, along with its parliaments, should maintain the protection of the state and its citizens.

entity15.name: sensors
entity15.description: Devices used for detecting or measuring a physical property and recording, indicating, or otherwise responding to it.

entity16.name: cameras
entity16.description: Imaging devices that capture visual information, often used in satellites for Earth observation.

entity17.name: planet's weather patterns
entity17.description: The atmospheric conditions or meteorological phenomena observed on a planet, particularly Earth.;;;The long-term weather patterns and conditions of the planet Earth.;;;Long-term average weather conditions in a particular area or globally.
entity17.chunkid: How Satellites Work22;;;How Satellites Work7;;;How Satellites Work21

entity18.name: meteorologists
entity18.description: Scientists who study the atmosphere and predict weather patterns.;;;Scientists who study and predict weather patterns using data from various sources including satellites.

entity20.name: laws of motion
entity20.description: A set of fundamental principles that describe the relationship between a body and the forces acting upon it, and its motion in response to those forces.

entity21.name: gravity
entity21.description: The natural force of attraction between physical bodies, especially when one of them is a celestial body like the Earth.

entity28.name: polar orbit
entity28.description: An orbit that passes above or nearly above both poles of the planet on each revolution.

entity29.name: payload
entity29.description: The equipment or instruments that perform the satellite's primary function.

entity30.name: bus
entity30.description: The structure that houses the payload and provides power, communication, and control systems.

entity32.name: solar panels
entity32.description: Devices that convert light, usually from the sun, into electrical power using photovoltaic cells.

entity33.name: sunlight
entity33.description: The natural light emitted by the Sun and received on Earth or other celestial bodies.

entity34.name: electricity
entity34.description: A form of energy resulting from the movement of charged particles, such as electrons, which can be used to power various devices and systems.

entity35.name: batteries
entity35.description: Electrical storage units that store chemical energy and convert it into electrical energy when needed.

entity37.name: radio signals
entity37.description: Electromagnetic waves used for transmitting information over distances through space or air.

entity38.name: Earth stations
entity38.description: Fixed or mobile installations on Earth's surface used for communicating with satellites and spacecraft.;;;Ground-based facilities equipped to transmit and receive signals from satellites in orbit.

entity41.name: equator
entity41.description: An imaginary line on the Earth's surface, equidistant from the North Pole and South Pole, dividing the Earth into Northern and Southern Hemispheres.

entity48.name: global connectivity
entity48.description: The ability to connect to a network or service from anywhere in the world, often facilitated by technology such as satellites.

entity49.name: remote and rural areas
entity49.description: Regions that are sparsely populated and far from urban centers, where access to traditional infrastructure is limited.

entity50.name: traditional infrastructure
entity50.description: The basic physical and organizational structures and facilities (e.g., buildings, roads, power supplies) needed for the operation of a society or enterprise.

entity53.name: Storms
entity53.description: Intense tropical storms with strong winds and heavy rain that form over warm ocean waters.;;;Severe weather conditions involving strong winds, heavy rain, thunder, and lightning.

entity55.name: Natural disasters
entity55.description: Catastrophic events caused by natural processes of the Earth, such as earthquakes, floods, and volcanic eruptions.

entity57.name: Tsunamis
entity57.description: Large ocean waves caused by underwater disturbances such as earthquakes or landslides.

entity60.name: oceans
entity60.description: Large bodies of saltwater that cover most of the Earth's surface.

entity61.name: atmosphere
entity61.description: The layer of gases surrounding the planet Earth, essential for life and weather processes.

entity62.name: land cover
entity62.description: The physical material at the surface of the earth, including vegetation, soil, rock, and human-made structures.

entity63.name: environmental monitoring
entity63.description: The process of observing and recording environmental conditions to assess changes over time.

entity64.name: conservation efforts
entity64.description: Actions taken to protect, preserve, or restore natural resources and ecosystems.

entity66.name: miniaturization
entity66.description: A process in which devices or systems are made smaller while maintaining or improving their functionality.

entity69.name: CubeSats
entity69.description: Small satellites that are revolutionizing the satellite industry by reducing costs and increasing accessibility.

entity71.name: educational institutions
entity71.description: Institutions that provide education at all levels, from primary to higher education.

entity72.name: startups
entity72.description: Newly established companies or ventures, often focused on developing and bringing a new product or service to market.

entity73.name: developing countries
entity73.description: Nations with lower levels of industrialization and generally lower standards of living compared to developed countries.

entity77.name: Laser communication technology
entity77.description: A method of transmitting information using laser beams for high-speed data transfer.

entity82.name: physics
entity82.description: The natural science that involves the study of matter, energy, and the interactions between them.

entity83.name: technology
entity83.description: The application of scientific knowledge for practical purposes, especially in industry, communications, and engineering.
